Dialogues.Dialogue: Come in!
Hello, welcome, its good to see that you could make it, have a seat.
Thank you, it's good to be here.
So let's get this started shall we?
Can I call you "Niccolo"?
A lot of people call me "Nicco", since it's way easier to say. Haha!
Haha! Alright, alright.
So Nicco, let's talk about your resume...
Mouse over the resume to highlight points of interest to you.
Yep, that's me. People also call me Nix.
That's my mobile phone number. I'd very much prefer to be emailed though!
Absolutely! the reception's just real bad over where I'm at. Leaving a voicemail is also good if you're unable to reach me!
You can view my LinkedIn profile here if you want: <color=lightblue><link=https://www.linkedin.com/in/niccojacinto>MyLinkedIn</link></color>
Send me a message by clicking <color=lightblue><link=mailto:niccolo.jacinto@gmail.com?subject=Hi%20There!&body=Nice%20resume!>here</link></color>!
That's my github profile, you can find it here: <color=lightblue><link=https://github.com/niccojacinto>Github Profile</link></color>
Visit me here: <color=lightblue><link=https://goo.gl/maps/NV693kDWnFPob98X7>Location</link></color>
Okay, that's not really where I live. It's classified.
Most of my projects, both professional and hobby ones are done in C#, so I'm most comfortable with that language.
I've protoyped a lot of mechanics I wanted to just 'try' out.
Sometimes they're part of a project, but most of the time they're not so I don't really save them.
Like.. there's this rubixcube-like meets tetris inventory style system I was playing around with for VR. It was quite fun to make. :D

I think I've reached the point where I want to work on projects on a slightly bigger scale. I believe I can start working on a project and learn from it since I am a blank slate and still have much to learn.
Yep. Like I said, I have much to learn from across different fields so I'm open to other roles as well.
C# is my preferred language, but I've also dabbled around other languages depending on the situation. It may take me a while to review and re-learn the language in question though.
Solving issues just comes with the job. Off by one errors, Heisenbugs (LOL), order of execution errors, design flaws.
While flying solo certainly is fun and liberating in its own way. I'm certain working with various and more experienced talents would shift the fun in a different way!
Eventually, I do want more experience working around Networking, exploring AI integration in games, more VR/AR applications, and last but not least.. procedural generation concepts.

Pretty straightforward here... you can see tools I've used, but didn't necessarily include a lot of detail. For example.. I mostly use Linux Mint for just powering my slowly dying laptop that I rarely use.

Might seem weird having this, but I did take a slight interest in data. Also from what I've learned, there can be game applications from it, and it does involve some degree of programming using Python for example.

This is my I.T. bit. It's very fundamental, but it did give me a small glimpse of the IT world. I was also reading Michel Meyer's CompTIA on the side (although never actually took the certification) and there was a LOT of information there I wouldn't have normally come across.
I took game programming courses in Humber. I was quite stressful but also fun! Shoutout to Kris Alexander! (definitely a passionate guy when it comes to games)
